The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of interest to both the scientific community and the public because of their potential as biocontrol agents and because of their close relationship to the group of animals that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids. We present a comprehensive analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for survival as parasites. Our results suggest that the transition from a free-living to a parasitic lifestyle was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host antiviral responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to persist and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) and thereby impair the antiviral transcriptional response. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is involved in nuclear import of ISGs. We show that the interaction between Orf6 and the Nup98-Rae1 complex is essential for the ability of Orf6 to block nuclear import of ISGs and to impair the IFN response. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be used by other viruses to interfere with the host antiviral response. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet in understanding the ecology and evolution of large mammals. (Less)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses are already experiencing layoffs and closures, and that the expected length of the crisis is negatively associated with the probability of closure. Moreover, businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and sinking. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is a major topic of research. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system formed in a relatively short time after the beginning of the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of parental care and domestication. Here, we show that all forms of external energy provisioning, including domestication and allonursing, are associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the evolution of parental care and domestication is not a trade-off between the amount of energy available to the mother and the amount of energy available to the offspring. Rather, it is a trade-off between the amount of energy available to the mother and the amount of energy available to the next generation. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the evolution of parental care and domestication is not a trade-off between the amount of energy available to the mother and the amount of energy available to the offspring. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance, as there are no treatments available to date.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance and auxiliary signals, including signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in human health. However, the potential of the microbiome to produce natural products that could be used as drugs is largely unknown. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut produce a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and therapeutics. These results suggest that the gut microbiome may be a source of natural products that could be used to treat a variety of diseases.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover composite structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties and seamlessly integrated into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and fabricate function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and fabricate mechanical devices with programmable behaviors. It is expected to inspire the development of mechanical devices with programmable behaviors in the future.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, can reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. This is accomplished by a reduction in the expression of the adult hemoglobin alpha chain and a concomitant increase in the expression of the fetal hemoglobin gamma chain. This mechanism of chronoregulation may be important for the development of fetal hemoglobin in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of effective therapies is a major challenge. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, and that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies for cancer that target the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and ferroptosis. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is the class of drugs that block L-type Ca2+ channels (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure in patients. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a pathway that promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forests. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, the only approved acylide antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active than the best candidate in a previous study. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study demonstrate the potential of computational design of antibiotics. This approach can be applied to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. It can also be used to design new molecules for other diseases.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many image-processing problems. We hope that this work will help to make deep learning more accessible to a wider audience.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. The species flock is a group of closely related cichlid species that evolved in a single lake, and the rapid diversification of the species flock is thought to be a response to environmental change. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The record also shows that the evolution of the species flock coincided with a period of extreme drought. The results highlight the importance of understanding the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. (Less)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but its cause is still debated. One hypothesis is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotopic composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopic compositions of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that they are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system has been extensively studied, but the function of CTLA-4 in the adult organism is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deletion induced a more severe disease than congenital deficiency, and the disease was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion had opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of molecular and morphological data to infer the evolutionary history of beetles, and to trace the evolution of genes that enabled the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the origin of beetles and angiosperms coincided with the codiversification of beetles and microbes, and that the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls was a key factor in the subsequent diversification of beetles.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines. This work provides a promising strategy for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cultural systems, and that the optimal population size may depend on the specific cultural system being evolved. This is an important finding for evolutionary psychology, as it suggests that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cultural systems.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the strongest risk factor. APOE is also a major protein in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,300 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 12.1 g/cm3, which is 40% higher than that of the outer core. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. This study shows that the inner core formed by a two-step nucleation process, which is a crystallization process of molten iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It is expected that this study will contribute to the understanding of the Earth's interior.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are not well understood, the drug is associated with negative consequences, including addiction. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are blunted in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the blunted brain responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors and negative emotions.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most accurate deep learning models for language processing also predict the brain’s responses to spoken sentences, across multiple datasets and multiple imaging modalities. We also show that model architecture contributes to brain response prediction, and that brain and model fits to behavioral responses are correlated. These results provide computational evidence for a predictive mechanism in the brain’s language processing system. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for how the brain computes about the world. If so, it may be a target for therapeutic intervention in neuropsychiatric disorders.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still with us today. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the cause of the other form of leprosy, diffuse lepromatous leprosy, has remained a mystery. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, a leprosy bacterium that causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the study of ancient pathogens. (Show more)

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum dynamics is a fundamental problem in quantum mechanics. In particular, the question of how the entropy of a system evolves during the time evolution is of central importance. This question has been addressed in the context of quantum quenches, where the system is driven out of equilibrium by a sudden change of its Hamiltonian. However, the study of the entanglement dynamics in the time evolution ensuing from a pure state is much more challenging. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit for the study of quantum quenches. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a long-standing challenge.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against COVID-19 is a top priority. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by the University of Oxford. The vaccine is based on recoding the viral spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine was shown to be highly attenuated in vitro and in vivo, and to induce high levels of spike-specific antibodies. In a relevant hamster model, the vaccine protected against lethal challenge with wild-type virus. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model outbreaks, which allows for the inclusion of uncertainty in the model parameters and the results. The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of evolution, has been less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also not the same in birds and mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is critical for the efficient severing of highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our results provide a molecular understanding of how ADF can efficiently sever actin filaments in cells. They also provide a general mechanism for understanding the action of proteins that bind to filaments in a mechanical context.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters because it is calorie-free. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake are unclear. Here, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose and may promote feeding behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred from one person to another. We show that this occurs even when people are not interacting in person, and even when they are not aware that the other person is influencing their emotions. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. They also suggest that people’s emotions are more malleable than previously thought.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation, and the presence of chemical modifications in coding regions can have profound effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in mRNA can have a modest effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a codon, and that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can increase the rate of protein synthesis from a given mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have a modest effect on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or by outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study highlights the importance of a sense of purpose in sustaining positive outcomes across the life course. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining characteristic of aquatic mammals. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The common cold virus, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infections. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that the replication of rhinovirus in mouse airway cells is temperature dependent, and that this temperature dependence is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanism of rhinovirus temperature dependence and for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat the common cold. The ability to sense the environment is a key feature of life. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is a unique mechanism that has not been described in bacteria. We propose a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, and the signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term surface attachment. This mechanism is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacterium to increase its virulence and biofilm formation in response to the mechanical activity of its pili. This study provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. It also demonstrates that bacteria can use pili as a sensor to regulate their own gene expression. This is a significant finding that has implications for understanding the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of bacterial virulence. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the resulting contamination of surface waters is a major concern. However, the extent of pesticide contamination of surface waters has not been comprehensively quantified. We provide a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This information is essential for the development of effective strategies to mitigate the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been largely overlooked. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal that is susceptible to infection. Our findings suggest that the virus may be circulating in deer, and that the presence of the virus in deer may facilitate the spread of the virus between humans and deer. This has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the problems and solutions to the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. We find that the problems are not insurmountable, but that the solutions are not being implemented.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the presence of extracellular plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles. However, the earliest pathological changes in AD are not associated with these pathologies, and the molecular mechanisms that lead to the development of these changes are not well understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and that they are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of extracellular plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, and may be a significant contributor to the pathogenesis of AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. The majority of the chicken bones at Maresha belong to adult individuals, and the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones is indicative of a selective breeding program. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how it proceeds. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in a complex manner. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein proceeds in distinct steps, and that the steps are adjacent in the native protein. These results suggest that the steps are not independent, and that the steps are native-like intermediates.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the function of Np4 as a precursor to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4, RppH, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs in cells experiencing disulfide stress. We also show that RppH prefers to recognize Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. This shift in substrate specificity, coupled with the unconventional manner in which Np4-capped 5′ ends bind to the active site of RppH, could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine deprivation is a common mechanism involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a therapeutic strategy in other conditions in which arginine deprivation is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the global biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s evolution is controlled by a critical current. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and has a low fracture toughness, limiting its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned by strain. We also show that diamond can be transformed into graphite under strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the relationship between the bandgap and the electronic structure of diamond. Our findings are expected to inspire new research directions in diamond science and technology.

The study of the molecular mechanisms of action of antimicrobial peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. Here, we report the structural and functional characterization of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, which is expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. The peptide is highly dynamic and has a unique structure, which is stabilized by two disulfide bonds. It exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens, and it binds to bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The peptide also exhibits strong cell wall binding and penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The results provide insights into the structural and functional features of this class of peptides, which may be useful in the development of new classes of antimicrobial agents. This work also illustrates the potential of the model legume Medicago truncatula as a tool for the study of the molecular mechanisms of action of antimicrobial peptides.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately connected to the female reproductive tract. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of sperm in the female reproductive tract is enriched with female-derived proteins, suggesting that the female reproductive tract may provide a source of proteins to support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The common human bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), is caused by mutations in the ultralong protein von Willebrand factor (VWF). The mutations alter the binding of VWF to platelets, but the mechanism is not known. Here we show that the mutations can be explained by a switch in the conformation of the protein, from a state with slow binding to one with fast binding. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of force on the binding. The mechanism is also consistent with the effects of mutations in other proteins that are involved in the regulation of blood clotting.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the human virome has been much less studied, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to study the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is also used to show that the human virome is much more complex than the bacteriome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the Earth’s climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We conducted continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. Our ACI analysis shows increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important because it is the temperature at which life as we know it can exist. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from isotopic data to have decreased over geological time. However, the isotopic data have been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We show that ancestral enzymes, which are the building blocks of the proteins that make up life, provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of cell excitability and the regulation of ion homeostasis. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are regulated by two types of gates, the intracellular gate and the selectivity filter gate. The intracellular gate is a bundle-crossing gate, and the selectivity filter gate is a pore gate. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of cell excitability and the regulation of ion homeostasis.

The malaria parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including the binding of its erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to GPA leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Therefore, it is desirable to explore the possibility of modifying its properties by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain levels, and that the bandgap can be made to vanish. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This relationship is important for understanding the stability of diamond under strain and for developing diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus infection is a major health concern in humans and animals. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice lacking the effector caspase-1/11, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus disease. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to involve a tree-like structure, in which sentences are built up from phrases, which are in turn built up from words. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly increases when words can be merged into a phrase. This suggests that the brain applies a merge operation to words, which is similar to the merge operation that applies to phrases in a tree. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream.

Vertebrate cells have two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of gene redundancy and the regulation of redundant genes in the context of a signaling pathway. It also provides a resource for studying the regulation of redundant genes in general. This work is of interest to a broad audience, including biologists, bioinformaticians, and computer scientists.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the LH (LH GABA) promotes eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the nitrogen cycle and is of great importance for agriculture. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria as biofertilizers is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the onset of symbiosis. Here, we demonstrate that the production of a signaling molecule by the host plant can be used to control the onset of symbiosis between the host plant and the nitrogen-fixing bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a signaling molecule in transkingdom signaling. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of symbiosis and on the development of sustainable agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise because of the large number of confounding factors. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We show that the climate and health effects of fossil-fuel-related emissions are more severe than previously thought. We also show that the health benefits of reducing emissions are much larger than previously estimated. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of a safe and effective vaccine is critical to ending the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and protection in mice. This variant is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine, as it is easy to manufacture, has high affinity to ACE2, and can be presented on a VLP. This variant can be used to develop a vaccine that can be manufactured at a large scale, which is critical to global access.

The role of ALK in human cancer has been established by the discovery of ALK mutations in neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is conserved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We also show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. Our results provide evidence that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is an important finding, as it suggests that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of human tissues as well. This is also the first report of a ligand–receptor system in which the ligand is a kinase. Our findings have important implications for the development of ALK inhibitors for the treatment of neuroblastoma and other ALK-driven cancers.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a unique window into the formative years of plague. Our results suggest that the plague lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic that devastated the Roman Empire and beyond was not a single, but a series of closely related lineages that spread across Eurasia. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which may have contributed to the spread of plague to Europe. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of its emergence. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity, HM) and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM. (PsycInfo Database Record … Continue reading)

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on the quantity and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC). In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to a loss of SOC, but the extent to which this trend can be reversed is unknown. We show that soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and the use of manure, can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a pathway for the restoration of soil organic carbon in agricultural landscapes. This work provides a framework for the design of future research and management practices to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was validated by the known zoonotic potential of the top 12. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important cue for animals to find and consume it. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of red nectar in two other plant species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, and provide evidence that the red color is a selective advantage for pollinators. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a common and widespread trait in nectar-feeding animals, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of nectar color. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood, as there are no genome sequences from this period. Here we present genome sequences from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 500 and 700 AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of these individuals indicates that women had a much more complex history than men, with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the demographic processes that occurred during the Early Middle Ages and suggest that the genetic history of Europe during this period was more complex than previously thought.

The coronavirus MERS-CoV has caused ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and the origin of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a rationale for the development of a universal vaccine against bat coronaviruses.
