The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) on sera from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, and where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate epidemics. (Show more)

The lagging strand of the double helix is synthesized by DNA polymerases in a 3′ to 5′ direction. In humans, this process is carried out by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical to the fidelity of lagging strand replication, but the nature of this stability is unknown. We developed a unique kinetic assay to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is loosely associated with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the nature of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in DNA replication. It also provides a framework for understanding the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this paper, we describe a method for the in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This polymerase can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the in vitro evolution of a functional RNA polymerase and the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents who live there.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can significantly improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of xanthocillin and other isocyanide metabolites suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present day surface temperature of 21 °C. Tridymite is a common mineral in terrestrial volcanic rocks, and the presence of such a mineral in a sedimentary deposit on Mars suggests that the sediment was deposited in a volcanic setting. The sedimentary deposit at Marias Pass, Gale crater, is a likely source of the tridymite, feldspar, magnetite, and amorphous silica in the bulk sample. The presence of these cogenetic minerals suggests that the sediment was deposited in a volcanic setting, possibly in a crater wall/rim/central peak.

Frost is a major abiotic stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of woody plants. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether the Th17 phenotype is maintained in the cells that contribute to disease. Here we show that the Th17 phenotype is maintained in a subset of Th17 cells, but not in a subset that is capable of supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by two mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms that control this plasticity may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic risk factors, such as the C9orf72 hexanucleotide expansion. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for drugs that alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will enable the development of new therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen colonization and disease. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick I. scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s colonization. We also show that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and facilitate colonization. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of modern avian form. Here, we report a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The reason for this is not well understood, but it is thought to be related to the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood of vertebrates. In this study, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this is due to the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin. We also show that these proteins are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green coloration in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a key feature of the tumor microenvironment, and is associated with increased breast cancer incidence and poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes breast cancer are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the ability of breast cancer cells to initiate tumors in mice. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a promising target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is controversial, but the timing of the event is well established. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age model is used to evaluate the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and to establish a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be used to evaluate the timing of ecosystem recovery.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier against the invasion of pathogens and the immune system. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor for SARS-CoV-2, and show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the total US population, and a 2.10-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 3.05-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the Black and Latino populations, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our findings highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of an element are the key to understanding its behavior in chemical reactions. The chemical hardness is a key property of an element, and it is the second-order chemical potential. It is the energy required to add an electron to an atom. We show that the chemical hardness decreases with pressure, and we propose a modified Mulliken electronegativity, which is the negative of the chemical potential of the electron in a given atom relative to the vacuum. We show that the modified electronegativity decreases with pressure, and we propose a modified chemical hardness, which is the second-order chemical potential. We show that the modified chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive.

Climate change is expected to increase global temperatures, but the effects of fire on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, although the magnitude of the effect depends on the emissions scenario. Our results highlight the importance of human demography in shaping the future of fire and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. We show that our method can identify topics that are not captured by existing structured variables. We also show that our method can identify gender biases in topics and that these biases are consistent with known patterns in suicide and homicide. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. We hope that it will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we show that the first plague introductions into Europe were not only repeated, but also delayed by 15 ± 1 y. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not a single introduction, but rather a series of introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the spread of the plague and its impact on the history of Europe. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss has a significant impact on the ecosystem. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroid species) in the Pacific Northwest. The virus is present in the environment and in the tissues of the affected asteroids, suggesting that it is spread by the movement of infected animals. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids, and it is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of this group of animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. We show here that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that the antibodies can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment modality for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines. This work provides a promising strategy for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and often not quantified. We show how to convert the original categorical crop ratings into a continuous probabilistic variable, which can be used to build quantitative models of crop status. We demonstrate that this probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, has nation-wide validity, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural monitoring systems. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert networks in agricultural monitoring systems.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons are sufficient for memory. We show that the strength of memory depends on the time constant of the changes in excitability and that this determines the time required to retrieve information from memory. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the magnitude of future warming. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and show that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not increase with warming in most biomes, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results demonstrate that the response of soil respiration to warming will vary regionally, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is associated with a major reorganization of the plastid genome, which is now the only organelle with a parasitic lifestyle. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the extent of functional reduction, and that the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle is associated with a new rate equilibrium. These results have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the origin of the plastid genome in particular.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, has been a source of fascination for the scientific community. The discovery of quasicrystals in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic material, has been a source of fascination for the general public.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are essential for its success. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is a key step in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, and has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic ring is catalyzed by three classes of enzymes, and that their evolution is linked to the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS), a chronic inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the progression of EAE. The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This finding provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Show more)

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which cause Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1, which causes a Stormorken-like syndrome. These mutations result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos, recapitulating key aspects of Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases has been a major focus of research in the last decade. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are still poorly understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain is dependent on the expression of a fluorescent protein in a defined subset of neurons. We show that the spreading of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates is dependent on fusion protein 1. These results provide a model for the study of spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and a platform for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

The study of the immune system in bats is important for understanding the mechanisms of immune regulation and the evolution of the immune system. The immune system of bats is different from that of other mammals, and the immune system of bats is considered to be an immunologically privileged site for microbial community residence. In this study, we found that the submandibular salivary gland of the bat is an immunologically privileged site for microbial community residence, and the immunosuppressant protein MTX is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase, which is responsible for the generation of leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX is a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that occurs in cancer cells is a major target for cancer therapy. One metabolic pathway that is often deregulated in cancer is the one that converts serine to glycine, a precursor of the nucleotide thymidine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in this pathway. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of a subset of B-cell cancers, but is ineffective in blocking the growth of a different subset of B-cell cancers. This latter finding is rooted in the fact that the former subset of B-cell cancers have defective glycine import, a finding that may have implications for the design of new therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord suggests that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the 2D photonic crystal system will be a useful tool for many-body physics and quantum engineering.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major topic in plant science. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in the early diversification of the group is still debated. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia is an aquatic plant, and its study provides new insights into the early diversification of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. We estimate that global mean sea level rose by 14 ± 4 cm between 1980 and 2014, and we find that this rate of sea level rise is accelerating. This acceleration is consistent with the acceleration of global mean temperature over the same period.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern of increasing pain with age is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the promise of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high mortality rate. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the only approved drug is a broad-spectrum antiviral, remdesivir. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by the host just before dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria only at night, when the squid’s behavior requires the production of bioluminescence. This strategy allows the squid to control the activities of its symbionts, and to maintain a healthy symbiosis, by regulating the provision of a single nutrient. This is a strategy that may be used by other hosts to control the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

This paper describes a series of experiments that tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of school discipline, which is a major driver of the school–to–prison pipeline. It also has implications for the future of teacher education, which should focus on developing teachers’ capacity to empathize with students. Finally, it has implications for the future of school reform, which should focus on developing scalable interventions to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still poorly understood. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription. We found that the transcription fidelity is strongly dependent on the location of the alkylation. The minor-groove alkylation is more detrimental to transcription fidelity than the major-groove alkylation. The minor-groove alkylation is also more detrimental to the fidelity of the individual checkpoints than the major-groove alkylation. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. The results from the present study are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The first cleavages are also significant because they are required for infection into human lung-derived cells, which are relevant to lung infection. Therefore, the first cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV pathogenesis.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the world’s population are a key lever for reducing environmental impacts. However, the food system is also a major contributor to health problems, and the health benefits of dietary change are large. We show that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a cafeteria by 50% without a detectable rebound effect. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in many settings. It has the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing environmental impacts and improving population health.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is a major target for cancer cells to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of breast cancer cell lines expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of new therapeutics. The development of a small molecule inhibitor against SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 is a promising strategy for the treatment of COVID-19. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism of immune evasion.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. It arises when we have a large dataset and wish to find associations in it. The fact that we have cherry-picked the data means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The methods are illustrated with an analysis of the relationship between the size of the brain and the size of the heart in a large dataset of animals. The methods can be applied to any dataset and any statistical learning method. They can be used to find associations that were previously unknown. They can be used to find associations that are not there.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a transcription factor that induces the development of ECs from nonvascular cells. ETV2 is expressed in the skin and is involved in the development of the skin and blood vessels. In this study, we demonstrated that ETV2 induces the development of ECs from fibroblasts in vitro and in vivo. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. The discovery of the ligand for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a third ligand, augmentor, which is also a ligand for Ltk. We show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that the augmentor ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the physiological role of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a model for understanding the role of orphan RTKs in vivo. Finally, it provides a model for understanding the role of orphan RTKs in human disease.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with type 2 diabetes, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, leading to glucose intolerance. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (Show more)

The influenza A virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that infects birds and humans. It is responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into the virion. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, and the molecular details of the packaging mechanism are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for the selective packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. We propose that this interaction promotes the formation of a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions, which favors the packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells (ECs). The activation of these proatherosclerotic phenotypes is mediated by the endothelial cell response to the local hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement, (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience improvement, and (iii) neighborhoods that are physically close to other attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic well-being of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a chemosensory receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a model for the study of the evolution of insect–plant interactions. (Show more)

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to explain the observed clinical course of the disease, and we provide estimates of the parameters of the model. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the disease course. Our results provide a framework for the design of future clinical trials of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is accompanied by a loss of the coral’s color, which is caused by the expulsion of the algal symbionts. We show that the metabolic activity of the coral host is increased during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and lead to a loss of barrier function. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function and homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the second leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. In this study, we show that the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1 is enhanced in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and re-engrave mice. We also show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is enhanced in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1 is enhanced in breast cancer cells expressing ROR1. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is controversial, and the cause is unknown. We show that a volcanic eruption series at the start of the last deglaciation, at 17.7 ka, is coincident with a stratospheric ozone-depleting eruption series at Mount Takahe, New Zealand, and that the volcanic eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly caused a change in Southern Hemisphere circulation and climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, providing food, livelihoods, and recreation to hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We show that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor and undernourished, and that they are most vulnerable to overfishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to identify the locations of riverine fisheries and to prioritize their conservation and sustainable management. This information is critical for protecting the benefits that rivers provide to the poor and undernourished, as well as to the health of the planet.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after early development. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, it suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought in its ability to regenerate.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and mice. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in yeast, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in plants may have evolved from a similar mechanism.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a large number of neurons is simultaneously low. This resting state is the result of the activity of a much smaller number of functionally organized networks. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of these networks is strongly correlated with the functional organization of the brain. We also show that the metabolic activity of the default mode network is reduced in Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality can be partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain, and on the relationship between the metabolic and functional activity of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of eukaryotic mRNA. However, there are many other modifications of RNA, including the recently discovered 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA in bacteria. Whether this modification exists in eukaryotes remains unknown. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery has implications for understanding the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. It also provides a model for the production of 5′ NAD+ RNA in other organisms. The discovery of 5′ NAD+ RNA in yeast provides a foundation for the study of this modification in other organisms.

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is of great interest because of the potential role of DNA methylation in the development of diabetes complications. We studied DNA methylation in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes who participated in the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and its long-term follow-up, the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We found that DNA methylation at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes was altered during the DCCT and persisted for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. They also suggest that epigenetic alterations at specific loci may be used as biomarkers of metabolic memory. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. (PsycINFO Database Record

The role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem, and there is a need for new therapeutic strategies. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that some of them develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a target for the management of the disease.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato aroma and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss, and because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key determinant of ecosystem function. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the mammalian brain, playing a role in spatial memory and navigation. How the neurons in MEC are organized is a key question in understanding how the brain represents space. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a spatial map, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons in MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for understanding how the brain represents space. This article is protected by copyright. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene in dodder C. australis does not function in flowering induction. Instead, we demonstrate that the FT protein is able to move from the host to the parasite, where it is able to induce flowering. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. Understanding the mechanisms of flowering regulation in plants is important for the development of new strategies for the control of parasitic plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-producing cells, which leads to a reduction in the amount of dopamine in the brain. This, in turn, leads to a reduction in the amount of dopamine that is released by dopamine-producing cells in response to stimuli. This reduction in dopamine release is thought to be the cause of the motor symptoms of the disease. We show that the dopamine-producing cells in the substantia nigra are connected to the striatum, a brain region involved in the control of movement, by a system of fibers that originate in striosomes, the specialized nuclei of striated cells in the striatum. These striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent a specialized subsystem within the nigro–striato–nigral loop that is affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected to each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that generates a regular heartbeat by integrating signals from the heart’s electrical system and the Ca2+ content of its Ca2+ stores. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ stores in SANCs and is essential for the generation of a regular heartbeat. These findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which STIM1 regulates Ca2+ stores in SANCs and contributes to the generation of a regular heartbeat. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in silicon cell deposition and accumulation, as well as by an increase in jasmonate (JA) signaling. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect attack. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activation of macrophages, which is important for the immune response.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that it is sensitive to context and serial order, and that it can bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a mechanism for memory that is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the neural basis of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall and into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. (Show more)

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often dominated by a small number of large tributaries, but the role of smaller tributaries in coastal eutrophication has been overlooked. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake, but that nutrient loads from smaller tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrient inputs from small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal eutrophication, especially given the likelihood that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is made available to the network only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the network dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large number of fine-tuned initial conditions is a consequence of the rare combinations of cosmological parameters that are made available to the network.

The mechanisms by which the immune system can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the immune system can change the dynamics of the brain, which can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. This mechanism may explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying abrupt events in the geologic record. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was likely caused by a global warming event that was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that RSPO certification was associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.
